commander.name: Major-General John Harding
commander.previous_service: Previously GOC 7th Armoured Division briefly in January 1942. Returned to command May 7, 1942 after brief tenure by Major-General Frank Messervy. Led division during First Alamein and Battle of Alam Halfa (August-September 1942).

command.headquarters_location: Western Desert - El Alamein defensive line (July-September 1942)

M3 Grant.note: 75mm sponson gun, 37mm turret gun. Primary medium tank Q3 1942

M4 Sherman.note: 75mm gun. Limited early deliveries in Q3 1942, bulk arriving Q4

Water bowser.role: Water supply - critical for desert operations

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Mk II.note: Two field regiments (24 guns each) - 3rd RHA and 5th RHA

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm).note: Anti-tank troops, divisional level. More prevalent than Q1/Q2

Ordnance QF 2-pounder (40mm).note: Portee-mounted, largely phased out by Q3

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive operations at El Alamein. Short supply lines from Alexandria (100km) and Cairo (250km) provide significant advantage over Axis forces. Division positioned in prepared defensive line. Water supply more favorable than during mobile operations. Fuel reserves adequate for defensive posture and local counterattacks. Montgomery building up supplies for major offensive (planned for October). Priority: ammunition stockpiling and tank maintenance during defensive phase.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain and rocky desert (El Alamein defensive line, Western Desert)

subordinate_units.composition: 1st Royal Tank Regiment (RTR), 5th RTR, 4th County of London Yeomanry (CLY/Sharpshooters), 1st Rifle Brigade (Motor Battalion)
subordinate_units.notes: Main striking force. Grant tanks with some early Shermans arriving. Crusader III tanks with 6-pounder guns.

subordinate_units.composition: Royal Scots Greys, 4th/8th Hussars, 5th Royal Tank Regiment (reconnaissance)
subordinate_units.notes: Reconnaissance and flank protection. Stuart light tanks and armoured cars. 4th and 8th Hussars operating together.

subordinate_units.composition: 1/5th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment, 1/6th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment, 1/7th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment
subordinate_units.notes: Motor infantry component. Three battalions of Queen's Royal Regiment. Infantry support for armoured operations.
Mobile artillery support attached to armoured division.
Second field artillery regiment. Mobile fire support for armoured operations.

subordinate_units.composition: Multiple anti-tank batteries with 6-pounder and 2-pounder guns
subordinate_units.notes: Divisional anti-tank defense. Transition from 2-pounder to 6-pounder guns during Q3 1942.
Air defense for division. Mobile Bofors batteries.

subordinate_units.composition: Communications squadrons, wireless sections, line sections
subordinate_units.notes: Divisional communications network. Critical for coordination during operations.

subordinate_units.composition: Field squadrons, workshop sections, bridging sections
subordinate_units.notes: Mine clearance, bridging, demolitions. Critical defensive engineering at Alamein line.

subordinate_units.composition: Transport companies, supply columns, petrol company, water company
subordinate_units.notes: Royal Army Service Corps. Logistics support with short supply lines from Egypt.

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armoured division operating in defensive posture at El Alamein line (July-September 1942). Specialized in armoured counterattacks, reconnaissance in force, and defensive anchoring. 'Desert Rats' veteran desert warfare expertise applied to defensive operations.
special_capabilities: Veteran desert warfare experience (1940-1942 continuous operations)
Mobile counterattack operations from defensive positions
Tank gunnery excellence with Grant 75mm guns
Reconnaissance in depth with armoured cars
Defensive mine warfare and obstacle integration
tactical_innovations: Leaguer defensive formations adapted to fixed positions
Mixed tank squadrons (Grant/Sherman medium + Stuart light)
Integration with prepared defensive positions at El Alamein
Mobile artillery support using 25-pounders in defensive role
known_issues: Tank strength reduced from sustained operations (First Alamein July 1942)
Grant tanks vulnerable to German anti-tank guns (high silhouette)
Mixed tank types complicate maintenance and logistics
Defensive posture constrains traditional mobile operations
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive desert warfare modifications maintained: sun compasses, sand channels, condensers for water recovery, extra water and fuel stowage, desert camouflage patterns, goggles and respirators for dust storms. Division operating in familiar terrain with superior supply access compared to Axis. Defensive adaptations include integration with minefields and prepared positions.

scenario_suitability: First Battle of El Alamein defensive operations (July 1-27, 1942)
Defensive counterattack scenarios from prepared positions
Desert warfare scenarios on defensive line
special_rules: Desert Rats: +1 morale in desert terrain
Defensive Position: +5% defense modifier when operating from prepared positions
Combined Arms Excellence: Artillery support missions resolve one phase faster
Short Supply Lines: +1 to supply rolls (100-250km from Egyptian depots)
Grant 75mm Gun: +10% hit probability vs medium armor (sponson gun effectiveness)
Veteran Crews: +5% to hit for all tank types
Reconnaissance Excellence: +15% spotting range for armoured car units
Mixed Tank Types: -5% maintenance reliability due to logistical complexity

source: TM 30-410: Handbook on the British Army 1942 (US War Department, 90% confidence)
Battle Orders 028: Desert Rats - British 8th Army in North Africa 1941-43 (Osprey, 85% confidence)
Nafziger Collection: British Forces El Alamein 1942 (88% confidence)
First Alamein and Alam Halfa battle reports (Historical, 82% confidence)
Eighth Army War Diary Q3 1942 (Secondary, 78% confidence)
British Armoured Division establishment tables 1942 (Secondary, 80% confidence)
known_gaps: Exact tank distribution by regiment (allocated proportionally based on brigade strength)
Specific subordinate unit commander names (mostly unknown except brigade commanders)
Precise operational tank strength vs total on-strength (estimated 86% operational rate)
Detailed breakdown of support vehicle types within RASC companies
Exact water bowser and petrol bowser counts (estimated based on divisional establishment)
Chief of Staff name not found in available sources
Individual regiment/battalion reference files not yet created
Sherman tank numbers estimated (limited early deliveries Q3, bulk in Q4)
Commander appointment dates verified from 1941-Q4 and 1942-Q4 data
validation.notes: Data extrapolated from 1941-Q3, 1941-Q4, and 1942-Q4 versions with Q3 1942 historical context. Tank numbers reduced from Q4 levels reflecting First Alamein/Alam Halfa period. Grant tanks predominant with limited early Sherman deliveries (18 tanks vs 48 in Q4). Personnel strength maintained at standard British armoured division establishment (14,850). Supply/logistics data reflects favorable defensive position at El Alamein with short supply lines from Egypt (180km operational radius vs 280km in mobile operations). Weather data represents peak summer desert conditions (July-September). Brigade composition reflects historical records of 22nd Armoured Brigade and 4th Light Armoured Brigade structure during Alamein period. Commander John Harding verified from historical records (appointed May 7, 1942, continuing through Q3 and into Q4 until wounded in December).
